title: Activity reports critique and improvement plan
summary:
**Conversation Overview**

The user requested a comprehensive critique and improvement plan for two Training of Trainers (ToT) activity reports (authored by Robo and Nilam) for an insulation training program. They specifically asked for 5 pros and 5 cons for each report, clear improvement recommendations, and visualizations using Mermaid diagrams in an artifact document. The user emphasized accuracy, requesting that Claude avoid fabricating numbers (mentioning a previous "441% ROI" error) and use real quotes from participant feedback CSV files they provided.

Claude analyzed the uploaded materials including both activity reports, participant feedback forms, solar job placement data, and contract terms of reference. The analysis revealed that both reports were nearly identical, with the main issues being bloated navigation (82 table of contents references), duplicate feedback tables appearing in both main body and appendix, and inaccurate participant numbers. Claude created a comprehensive critique document with Mermaid process flow diagrams showing the training methodology and job linkage pathways.

The user's training program uses a "One Thing Per Day" pedagogical structure for insulation training, where each day focuses on one main concept, one hands-on activity, and one sharing component. Claude highlighted this as an effective learning approach that prevents cognitive overload through a Learn-Apply-Share loop. The actual participant data showed 8 insulation trainers provided feedback with an average clarity rating of 4.4/5, and included specific Arabic quotes about needing more site visits and psychological support for graduates entering the workforce.

Claude provided two merge options: the user could manually edit using the critique as a checklist, or Claude could create the merged version for review. The key recommendations included fixing participant numbers, removing duplicate tables, adding real participant quotes, inserting the "One Thing Per Day" structure table, and including process visualization diagrams to better showcase the training methodology.

## **1\) Executive Summary** {#1)-executive-summary}

**Over the course of September and October (Sept 1-2 for Solar, October 12–14 October 2025 and 15th October for Architecture),** Bilal, consulting with the ITC, and Mosul Space convened experts and potential trainers from the private sector and universities to align on delivering BEIT’s Insulation & Thermal Envelope module and its integration touchpoints with Solar and Architecture.   **2\) Background & Objectives**

  ### **2.1 Why Mosul Needs This (energy reality, perception gap)** {#2.1-why-mosul-needs-this-(energy-reality,-perception-gap)}

  Mosul’s homes are hot in summer, cold in winter, and expensive to run yet the business landscape addressing these challenges are still in their nascent stages. Families rely on diesel generators and inconsistent grid power; noise, fumes, and high bills are the norm, insulation is not common, and solar power is doubted as a viable alternative. Meanwhile, modern building practice has lost touch with its values-inspired, and climate-responsive traditions\*\*.\*\*  
  The bigger issue that trainers and other stakeholders mention over and over is the perception that many residents (and even contractors) have that either “nothing works” or “it’s too expensive.” Poor solar installs and under-spec’d insulation have damaged trust. This ToT targets both sides of the problem, ensuring that local talent knows how to do high-quality installations using appropriate materials (expensive is actually cheaper) and the story-sharing elements (credible, simple, and multifaceted evidence)

  ### **2.2 ToT Purpose & Audience** {#2.2-tot-purpose-&-audience}

  **Purpose.** Equip a trainer cohort to deliver the **Insulation & Thermal Envelope** module (with touchpoints to Solar and Architecture) so that **early-career engineers/technicians** can diagnose, recommend, and implement **80/20** retrofits with confidence.  
  **Audience.** Trainers who will teach **engineers and technical graduates** entering practice. They already speak the language of site work; they need **a simple teaching spine** and locally verified tools.  
  **Objectives (what trainers leave with)**  
    
1. **Method:** Use U-value and kWh reasoning (not “amps × IQD”) to make credible, comparable claims.  
     
2. **Pedagogy:** Run 3-station rotations (install • measure • document) with clear outputs (photo logs, ΔT sheets).  
     
3. **Decision support:** Teach with decision trees (roof/walls/windows) so choices are fast and defensible.  
     
4. **Market linkage:** Activate supplier calls, WhatsApp cohorts, and mentor follow-ups so learning turns into paid work.  
     
5. **Assessment:** Administer daily PRE \+ final POST mapped to constructs, with easy scoring and feedback loops.

   ### **2.3 Design Principles** {#2.3-design-principles}

* **80/20 first.** Five days demand focus: roofs, thermal coatings, and air-sealing/windows cover most gains for most homes.  
    
* **One clear message per day.** Every day ends with: *“If I only learned one thing today, it’s \_\_\_.”*  
    
* **kWh & U-value rigor.** We compute ΔU × ΔT → ΔkWh → tariff bands → payback (months/years); no shortcuts.  
    
* **Local verification.** All materials, prices, and installation steps are checked with Mosul suppliers and typical house constraints.  
    
* **Relationships as curriculum.** Supplier calls, peer groups, and trainer mentorship are deliberate learning outcomes, not extras.

  ### **2.4 “Actions by Intentions” Framing (service, public benefit, livelihoods)** {#2.4-“actions-by-intentions”-framing-(service,-public-benefit,-livelihoods)}

  We anchor the work in **service**: reduce waste and bills, **clean the air**, and **improve comfort**—while sustaining the livelihoods of those who build and retrofit. We remind ourselves of the Prophetic teaching that **actions are judged by intentions**.  
  **Intention for this module:** *Benefit families living with heat, cold, and high costs; honor Mosul’s heritage of climate-wise building; and equip a new workforce to earn with integrity.*

  ## **3\) Methodology & Pedagogy** {#3)-methodology-&-pedagogy}

  ### **3.1 Year-Long Expert Interviews → Curriculum Co-creation** {#3.1-year-long-expert-interviews-→-curriculum-co-creation}

  This ToT stands on a year of **field conversations** with Mosul practitioners (insulation, solar, architecture). These weren’t academic surveys—they were **problem sessions**: what fails on rooftops, where heat actually enters, what suppliers really carry, how clients decide.  
    
  **How co-creation shaped the module**  
    
* **Content spine:** Prioritize roof/thermal coatings/air-sealing as 80/20 wins; park edge cases for Q\&A.  
    
* **Financial literacy:** Lock kWh & U-value as the claim backbone; no “amps × IQD.”  
    
* **Learning design:** Emphasize hands-on rotation, measurable outputs, and decision-trees to cut through complexity.  
    
* **Tools:** ROI calculator, proposal template, supplier list—all localized for Mosul.  
  The October ToT simply brought the co-authors into one room to align, test, and finalize.

  ### **3.2 Stations Model (3 stations; 30–40 min rotations; documentation protocol)** {#3.2-stations-model-(3-stations;-30–40-min-rotations;-documentation-protocol)}

  We teach \~20 participants by splitting into **3 small groups (4–7 people)** rotating through **three stations**. Each rotation is **30–40 minutes**; one facilitator anchors each station; a runner floats.

| Station | Focus | What they do | Output (evidence) | Common pitfalls → Quick fix |
| :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- |
| **1\. Materials & R-Value** | Identify local materials; read labels/specs; infer R/U | Handle EPS/mineral wool/PU foam; read thickness; compute U \= 1/R; discuss moisture & fire notes | Photo of material \+ spec note, mini table of R/U by thickness | Confusing nominal vs effective R → Show example calc with real thickness |
| **2\. Install & Air-Sealing** | Practice technique on mock-ups | Cut/fit insulation; seal cracks with silicone/foam; tape seams; safe ladder stance | Before/After photo; checklist ticks (gaps sealed, overlaps, fasteners) | Messy sealant → Demonstrate bead size & tooling; missed gaps → smoke test |
| **3\. Measure & Document** | Turn physics into claims | IR/ΔT spot readings; estimate ΔkWh from ΔU × ΔT; fill ROI fields with local tariff | ΔT log, one ΔkWh → IQD payback snippet; exportable photo pair | Unstable ΔT → Warm IR 2–3 min, same angle/surface; wrong tariff → use banded sheet |

**Rotation rhythm (per group):**  
1–2 min brief → 20–25 min hands-on → 5–8 min document outputs → 2–3 min micro-debrief.  
**Facilitator roles:** teach *one* technique well; capture evidence; push “one clear takeaway” at the end.

**Documentation protocol (non-negotiable)**

* **Photo logs**: before/after, same angle, include a finger/marker for scale.  
    
* **ΔT sheets**: location, time, surface condition, ambient, **device warmed up**.  
    
* **Safety checks**: ladder footing, PPE, hot surfaces, electrical proximity.  
    
* **File naming**: `Team#_Station#_YYYYMMDD_Site/Mock_Label`. Upload to cohort drive at day-end.

  ### **3.3 Take-Home Practice (physical sample; learning extension)** {#3.3-take-home-practice-(physical-sample;-learning-extension)}

  Learning sticks when it **leaves the room**. Each participant takes **one small physical sample** to keep practicing and explaining to clients.  
    
* **Sample kit (pick one):** a 10×10 cm insulation piece (with label), a kāshi tile shard (reflectivity cue), or a sealant strip.  
    
* **Micro-assignment:** Replicate one measurement (ΔT or gap-seal test) at home; post photo \+ 2-line note in the WhatsApp group within 48 hours.  
    
* **Why it matters:** The object becomes a show-and-tell with family/clients; the WhatsApp post builds peer habit and a portfolio trail.

  ### **3.4 Localization & Heritage Cues (Mosul examples first)** {#3.4-localization-&-heritage-cues-(mosul-examples-first)}

  We **start local**—materials, prices, roof types, window habits—then generalize.  
    
* **Roofs:** Contrast inverted roof vs interior ceiling add-on; show kāshi reflectivity impact; discuss access constraints.  
    
* **Walls/windows:** Typical WWR, orientation, shading traditions; quick wins with air-sealing and curtains/shutters.  
    
* **Markets & suppliers:** Call actual suppliers during the session (“I’m a student, I’m learning”) to confirm stock and prices.  
    
* **Heritage lens:** Elicit memories (courtyard, high ceilings, thick walls) as design logic, not nostalgia.  
    
* **Language & claims:** Every claim ends in kWh and IQD, backed by local tariffs and before/after photos.

  ## **6\) Monitoring, Evaluation & Learning** {#6)-monitoring,-evaluation-&-learning}

  ### **6.1 Assessment Design (daily PRE; final POST; constructs; scoring)** {#6.1-assessment-design-(daily-pre;-final-post;-constructs;-scoring)}

  We kept assessments **short, scorable, and comparable** across days.  
    
* **Daily PREs (Days 1–5):** 8 minutes, **multiple choice (A–D)**, **\+1/0 scoring**, two parts per day:  
  **Part A—Skills & Learn (Q1–Q5)** and **Part B—Sell & Financial Literacy (Q6–Q8)**. This pattern is explicit on Day-1 and repeats consistently through the week.  
    
* **Final POST (Day-5):** 25–30 minutes, **30 MCQs**—**24 Skills & Learn (Q1–Q24)** \+ **6 Sell & Financial Literacy (Q25–Q30)**—mirrors the daily PRE constructs so we can compare like-with-like; **\+1/0** scoring.  
    
  **Constructs sampled (by day → what we check):**  
    
1. **Day 1:** heat pathways, ΔT basics, **U-value concept**, simple kWh numeracy; baseline problem story.  
     
2. **Day 2:** roof dominance, coating types, **coverage/ΔT mini-lab**, simple ROI & objections.  
     
3. **Day 3:** walls/windows, WWR targets, orientation logic, **BOQ quantities** and quote transparency.  
     
4. **Day 4:** retrofit planning, constraints, **transparent quoting & simple payback**.  
     
5. **Day 5 (PRE):** evidence protocol, next steps, **break-even & margin levers**.  
     
6. **Final POST:** aggregates the same mechanics—ΔT, U/kWh, roof/walls/windows choices, coverage math, payback, quote transparency, pitch close, break-even, margin hygiene.  
   **Cadence at a glance**

| Day(s) | When | Instrument | Coverage |
| :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- |
| 1–(last–1) | Morning | Daily PRE (short) | That day’s learning outcomes (kWh reasoning, U-value concept, simple misconceptions, hands-on observation prompts tied to the day’s demos/examples) |
| Last day | After training | Final POST | Aggregate of the module’s constructs taught across days, using the same examples and figures used in class (no new content) |

### **6.2 “One Clear Takeaway” closure** {#6.2-“one-clear-takeaway”-closure}

We close each day with a **one-line takeaway** from every trainer:

“**If I only learned one thing today, it’s…**”

This anchors the daily message discipline (simple \> exhaustive), and pairs with the PRE/POST by reinforcing the same constructs in plain language that we heard in the questions.

Collection method: short sticky or WhatsApp message per trainer; copy into the day’s folder. Use 3–5 of the best lines to open the next morning.

# **Training of Trainers (ToT) — Activity Report**

**Program:** Insulation & Heritage-Informed Housing (Mosul)  
**ToT Dates covered:** 12–14 October 2025   
**Prepared by:** Bilal Ghalib (ITC)  
**Implementing Partner:** Mosul Space

## **1\) Executive Summary** {#1)-executive-summary}

**Over the course of September and October (Sept 1-2 for Solar, October 12–14 October 2025 and 15th October for Architecture),** Bilal, consulting with the ITC, and Mosul Space convened experts and potential trainers from the private sector and universities to align on delivering BEIT’s Insulation & Thermal Envelope module and its integration touchpoints with Solar and Architecture. Over three days, trainers were trained on the “Learn, Apply, Sell” methodology, the pedagogy, verified materials and prices locally, and set established alignment on constructs so claims to clients are credible, comparable, and easy to teach.

The ToT also helped solidify a community of experts who have been coming together over the last year through ITC’s interventions, including the Hackathon, interviews, and roundtable discussions. The ecosystem for the sustainable housing and retrofitting industry is starting to take shape; experts who had worked separately are now connected and sharing ideas and supplier contacts. The group left with shared methods, shared tools (ROI calculator, proposal templates), and shared next steps. A cohort WhatsApp thread is live to keep the momentum beyond the room

### **1.1 What Was Accomplished** {#1.1-what-was-accomplished}

* **Cohort formed:** 44 Trainers (21 Solar, 14 Insulation, and 9 Architecture) contact list consolidated.  
* **Alignment on Pedagogy:** Learn Apply Sell as the overall structure over the course of 5 days, with hands-on work, sales practice, and homework agreed upon.  
* **Assessment finalized:** Daily PRE \+ final POST; scoring & answer keys prepared.  
* **Continuity set:** WhatsApp group launched, connections were formed, desire for future connections and continuity indicated.

  ### 

  ### **1.2 Three Core Insights** {#1.2-three-core-insights}

* **Coalition of Creators.** Trainers were the original creators for these modules, the co-creators, not contractors; the value is the community of practice that now troubleshoots together.  
* **Simplicity unlocks action.** The short 5-day delivery creates a focus on prioritizing high-impact retrofitting choices and one clear message per day  
* **Relationships \> Information.** Our goals with the training are to connect people with suppliers, with trainers who are active in the industry, and peers to reduce the actual and psychological barriers to getting youth into the market.

  ### **1.3 Three Recommendations** {#1.3-three-recommendations}

* **Green Home Festival/Fair (leverage Output 3.2).** Turn the design-competition finale into a jobs faire and/or conference. Bringing in supplier booths, job matching, mentor/co-founder meetups, graduate pitches, and media visibility.  
* **Digital Community Hub.** Lightweight directory for trainers, graduates, suppliers, materials, plus a searchable Q\&A so answers outlive individuals.  
* **Community continuity.** Keep the trainer community active in sharing on the whatsapp by sharing live updates during trainings, questions, and connections with participants. Twice a year, let’s convene the trainers to gather suggestions and ideas for improving the training material.  

  ### **1.4 Delivery Mechanisms (for participant-facing runs)** {#1.4-delivery-mechanisms-(for-participant-facing-runs)}

* **In-person (hands-on):** Station rotations for installation practice, measurement (IR/ΔT), and documentation; on-site safety checks; real material handling.  
* **Digital (support pack):** ROI calculator, tariff lookups, proposal template, post-day quiz/reflection, and micro-videos—ready for low-friction reuse by trainers.

  ### **1.5 Evidence Mini-Summary (on file; see Annexes)** {#1.5-evidence-mini-summary-(on-file;-see-annexes)}

* **Attendance snapshot:** full register with signatures attached.  
* **Feedback themes (top-3):** (1) more hands-on time, (2) clearer sequencing via decision trees, (3) keep kWh/U-value rigor.  
* **Artifacts captured:** signed registers; training photos, trainer interviews transcribed  
  **2\) Background & Objectives**

  ### **2.1 Why Mosul Needs This (energy reality, perception gap)** {#2.1-why-mosul-needs-this-(energy-reality,-perception-gap)}

  Mosul’s homes are hot in summer, cold in winter, and expensive to run yet the business landscape addressing these challenges are still in their nascent stages. Families rely on diesel generators and inconsistent grid power; noise, fumes, and high bills are the norm, insulation is not common, and solar power is doubted as a viable alternative. Meanwhile, modern building practice has lost touch with its values-inspired, and climate-responsive traditions**.**   
  The bigger issue that trainers and other stakeholders mention over and over is the perception that many residents (and even contractors) have that either “nothing works” or “it’s too expensive.” Poor solar installs and under-spec’d insulation have damaged trust. This ToT targets both sides of the problem, ensuring that local talent knows how to do high-quality installations using appropriate materials (expensive is actually cheaper) and the story-sharing elements (credible, simple, and multifaceted evidence)

  ### **2.2 ToT Purpose & Audience**  {#2.2-tot-purpose-&-audience}

  **Purpose.** Equip a trainer cohort to deliver the **Insulation & Thermal Envelope** module (with touchpoints to Solar and Architecture) so that **early-career engineers/technicians** can diagnose, recommend, and implement **80/20** retrofits with confidence.  
  **Audience.** Trainers who will teach **engineers and technical graduates** entering practice. They already speak the language of site work; they need **a simple teaching spine** and locally verified tools.  
  **Objectives (what trainers leave with)**  
1. **Method:** Use U-value and kWh reasoning (not “amps × IQD”) to make credible, comparable claims.  
2. **Pedagogy:** Run 3-station rotations (install • measure • document) with clear outputs (photo logs, ΔT sheets).  
3. **Decision support:** Teach with decision trees (roof/walls/windows) so choices are fast and defensible.  
4. **Market linkage:** Activate supplier calls, WhatsApp cohorts, and mentor follow-ups so learning turns into paid work.  
5. **Assessment:** Administer daily PRE \+ final POST mapped to constructs, with easy scoring and feedback loops.

   ### **2.3 Design Principles** {#2.3-design-principles}

* **80/20 first.** Five days demand focus: roofs, thermal coatings, and air-sealing/windows cover most gains for most homes.  
* **One clear message per day.** Every day ends with: *“If I only learned one thing today, it’s \_\_\_.”*  
* **kWh & U-value rigor.** We compute ΔU × ΔT → ΔkWh → tariff bands → payback (months/years); no shortcuts.  
* **Local verification.** All materials, prices, and installation steps are checked with Mosul suppliers and typical house constraints.  
* **Relationships as curriculum.** Supplier calls, peer groups, and trainer mentorship are deliberate learning outcomes, not extras.

  ### **2.4 “Actions by Intentions” Framing (service, public benefit, livelihoods)** {#2.4-“actions-by-intentions”-framing-(service,-public-benefit,-livelihoods)}

  We anchor the work in **service**: reduce waste and bills, **clean the air**, and **improve comfort**—while sustaining the livelihoods of those who build and retrofit. We remind ourselves of the Prophetic teaching that **actions are judged by intentions**.  
  **Intention for this module:** *Benefit families living with heat, cold, and high costs; honor Mosul’s heritage of climate-wise building; and equip a new workforce to earn with integrity.*


  ## **3\) Methodology & Pedagogy** {#3)-methodology-&-pedagogy}

  ### **3.1 Year-Long Expert Interviews → Curriculum Co-creation** {#3.1-year-long-expert-interviews-→-curriculum-co-creation}

  This ToT stands on a year of **field conversations** with Mosul practitioners (insulation, solar, architecture). These weren’t academic surveys—they were **problem sessions**: what fails on rooftops, where heat actually enters, what suppliers really carry, how clients decide.

  **How co-creation shaped the module**  
* **Content spine:** Prioritize roof/thermal coatings/air-sealing as 80/20 wins; park edge cases for Q\&A.  
* **Financial literacy:** Lock kWh & U-value as the claim backbone; no “amps × IQD.”  
* **Learning design:** Emphasize hands-on rotation, measurable outputs, and decision-trees to cut through complexity.  
* **Tools:** ROI calculator, proposal template, supplier list—all localized for Mosul.  
   The October ToT simply brought the co-authors into one room to align, test, and finalize.

  ### **3.2 Stations Model (3 stations; 30–40 min rotations; documentation protocol)** {#3.2-stations-model-(3-stations;-30–40-min-rotations;-documentation-protocol)}

  We teach \~20 participants by splitting into **3 small groups (4–7 people)** rotating through **three stations**. Each rotation is **30–40 minutes**; one facilitator anchors each station; a runner floats.

| Station | Focus | What they do | Output (evidence) | Common pitfalls → Quick fix |
| ----- | ----- | ----- | ----- | ----- |
| **1\. Materials & R-Value** | Identify local materials; read labels/specs; infer R/U | Handle EPS/mineral wool/PU foam; read thickness; compute U \= 1/R; discuss moisture & fire notes | Photo of material \+ spec note, mini table of R/U by thickness | Confusing nominal vs effective R → Show example calc with real thickness |
| **2\. Install & Air-Sealing** | Practice technique on mock-ups | Cut/fit insulation; seal cracks with silicone/foam; tape seams; safe ladder stance | Before/After photo; checklist ticks (gaps sealed, overlaps, fasteners) | Messy sealant → Demonstrate bead size & tooling; missed gaps → smoke test |
| **3\. Measure & Document** | Turn physics into claims | IR/ΔT spot readings; estimate ΔkWh from ΔU × ΔT; fill ROI fields with local tariff | ΔT log, one ΔkWh → IQD payback snippet; exportable photo pair | Unstable ΔT → Warm IR 2–3 min, same angle/surface; wrong tariff → use banded sheet |

  **Rotation rhythm (per group):**  
   1–2 min brief → 20–25 min hands-on → 5–8 min document outputs → 2–3 min micro-debrief.  
  **Facilitator roles:** teach *one* technique well; capture evidence; push “one clear takeaway” at the end.

  **Documentation protocol (non-negotiable)**

* **Photo logs**: before/after, same angle, include a finger/marker for scale.  
* **ΔT sheets**: location, time, surface condition, ambient, **device warmed up**.  
* **Safety checks**: ladder footing, PPE, hot surfaces, electrical proximity.  
* **File naming**: `Team#_Station#_YYYYMMDD_Site/Mock_Label`. Upload to cohort drive at day-end.

  ### **3.3 Take-Home Practice (physical sample; learning extension)** {#3.3-take-home-practice-(physical-sample;-learning-extension)}

  Learning sticks when it **leaves the room**. Each participant takes **one small physical sample** to keep practicing and explaining to clients.  
* **Sample kit (pick one):** a 10×10 cm insulation piece (with label), a kāshi tile shard (reflectivity cue), or a sealant strip.  
* **Micro-assignment:** Replicate one measurement (ΔT or gap-seal test) at home; post photo \+ 2-line note in the WhatsApp group within 48 hours.  
* **Why it matters:** The object becomes a show-and-tell with family/clients; the WhatsApp post builds peer habit and a portfolio trail.

  ### **3.4 Localization & Heritage Cues (Mosul examples first)** {#3.4-localization-&-heritage-cues-(mosul-examples-first)}

  We **start local**—materials, prices, roof types, window habits—then generalize.  
* **Roofs:** Contrast inverted roof vs interior ceiling add-on; show kāshi reflectivity impact; discuss access constraints.  
* **Walls/windows:** Typical WWR, orientation, shading traditions; quick wins with air-sealing and curtains/shutters.  
* **Markets & suppliers:** Call actual suppliers during the session (“I’m a student, I’m learning”) to confirm stock and prices.  
* **Heritage lens:** Elicit memories (courtyard, high ceilings, thick walls) as design logic, not nostalgia.  
* **Language & claims:** Every claim ends in kWh and IQD, backed by local tariffs and before/after photos.

  ### **4.3 Key Moments** {#4.3-key-moments}

* **The numbers settled the argument.** One trainer proposed interior roof insulation due to site constraints; others challenged. A 20-minute whiteboard ROI with ΔU × ΔT → ΔkWh → IQD showed when interior works (and when it doesn’t). Result: shared judgment, not opinions.

  ## **5\) Materials Produced** {#5)-materials-produced}

  We kept the kit **lean and coherent**: **Facilitator Guide \+ Canva visuals \+ Meet the Materials \+ one Workbook** as the **single source of truth**, plus **Daily Homework Packs (PDF)** for participant practice and evidence. Everything is localized to Mosul (materials, prices, tariffs).

  ### **5.1 Core Trainer Files (what runs the room)** {#5.1-core-trainer-files-(what-runs-the-room)}

  ### **5.2 Workbook** {#5.2-workbook}

  All calculations, choices, quotes, and ROI live in **one workbook**. Trainers and participants use the same file across **Day 1 → Day 5**.

| **Investment Analysis** | 4 | Convert **ΔU×ΔT → ΔkWh → IQD (banded)** → **payback** | 1-slide pitch numbers (Investment, Savings, Payback) |

| **Business Dashboard / Marketing ROI** | 5 | Simple KPIs \+ testimonials | Cohort debrief data |

  ### **5.3 Daily Homework Packs** {#5.3-daily-homework-packs}

  Each homework is a **1–2 page** PDF the cohort can print, complete, and submit as photos via WhatsApp. The packs already mirror **Learn → Apply → Sell** and tie directly to workbook tabs and our kWh/U-value method.

  **What you already have (by day)**

* **Day 1 — Home Audit & 30-sec Hook**  
   Participants submit a before-photo, fill the audit entry (Room, Temp °C, Leak), identify daily amp pattern, and draft a 30-sec hook (problem → proof → benefit).  
* **Day 2 — Roof ➜ Suppliers ➜ ROI**  
   Assess roof and add photos; pick one roof intervention in Solution Designer; call/log suppliers (price, MOQ, lead time); calculate ROI via **Tariff\_Calc → Investment Analysis**; deliver a 60-sec SELL pitch with roof rationale, price, savings, payback.  
* **Day 3 — Walls/Windows ➜ BOQ ➜ Revenue Draft**  
   Measure exposure areas and orientation; choose max two interventions; build a BOQ; run ROI in **Investment Analysis (CUSTOM)**, set a margin and price; draft revenue; (optional) reel title for WhatsApp.  
* **Day 4 — Investment Pitch (1-slide, local tariff)**  
   Select package from **Investment Analysis**; set **tiered** local tariff (no flat rate); confirm Investment, Monthly Savings, Payback; build the slide with client/site, package, numbers, supplier/warranty/installation window, photos, CTA; export to WhatsApp.

  ## **6\) Monitoring, Evaluation & Learning** {#6)-monitoring,-evaluation-&-learning}

  ### **6.1 Assessment Design (daily PRE; final POST; constructs; scoring)** {#6.1-assessment-design-(daily-pre;-final-post;-constructs;-scoring)}

  We kept assessments **short, scorable, and comparable** across days.

* **Daily PREs (Days 1–5):** 8 minutes, **multiple choice (A–D)**, **\+1/0 scoring**, two parts per day:  
  **Part A—Skills & Learn (Q1–Q5)** and **Part B—Sell & Financial Literacy (Q6–Q8)**. This pattern is explicit on Day-1 and repeats consistently through the week.  
* **Final POST (Day-5):** 25–30 minutes, **30 MCQs**—**24 Skills & Learn (Q1–Q24)** \+ **6 Sell & Financial Literacy (Q25–Q30)**—mirrors the daily PRE constructs so we can compare like-with-like; **\+1/0** scoring.

  **Constructs sampled (by day → what we check):**  
1. **Day 1:** heat pathways, ΔT basics, **U-value concept**, simple kWh numeracy; baseline problem story.  
2. **Day 2:** roof dominance, coating types, **coverage/ΔT mini-lab**, simple ROI & objections.  
3. **Day 3:** walls/windows, WWR targets, orientation logic, **BOQ quantities** and quote transparency.  
4. **Day 4:** retrofit planning, constraints, **transparent quoting & simple payback**.

5. **Day 5 (PRE):** evidence protocol, next steps, **break-even & margin levers**.  
6. **Final POST:** aggregates the same mechanics—ΔT, U/kWh, roof/walls/windows choices, coverage math, payback, quote transparency, pitch close, break-even, margin hygiene.   
   **Cadence at a glance**

| Day(s) | When | Instrument | Coverage  |
| ----- | ----- | ----- | ----- |
| 1–(last–1) | Morning | Daily PRE (short) | That day’s learning outcomes (kWh reasoning, U-value concept, simple misconceptions, hands-on observation prompts tied to the day’s demos/examples) |
| Last day | After training | Final POST | Aggregate of the module’s constructs taught across days, using the same examples and figures used in class (no new content) |

   

   ### **6.2 “One Clear Takeaway” closure** {#6.2-“one-clear-takeaway”-closure}

   We close each day with a **one-line takeaway** from every trainer:

   “**If I only learned one thing today, it’s…**”

   This anchors the daily message discipline (simple \> exhaustive), and pairs with the PRE/POST by reinforcing the same constructs in plain language that we heard in the questions.

   Collection method: short sticky or WhatsApp message per trainer; copy into the day’s folder. Use 3–5 of the best lines to open the next morning.

- [ ] Every number cited exists in your CSV files

- [ ] No duplicate tables between main body and appendix
- [ ] At least one visual diagram included

- [ ] Job linkage section emphasizes hands-on learning (not hypothetical frameworks)
- [ ] Executive Summary can stand alone without reading full report
- [ ] Recommendations are concrete enough for ITC to action

---

## Appendix: What Makes This Pedagogy Actually Good

Your "One Thing Per Day" structure isn't just clear - it solves a real problem in technical training. Here's why it works:

### The Problem With Most Technical Training

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Day 1: Theory Overload] --> B[Day 2: More Theory]
    B --> C[Day 3: Even More Theory]
    C --> D[Day 4: Quick Lab Demo]
    D --> E[Day 5: Exam]
    E --> F[Participants Forget Everything]
    
    style F fill:#ffcdd2
```

### Your Learn-Apply-Share Loop

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Morning: ONE Concept] --> B[Afternoon: Touch It]
    B --> C[Homework: Share It]
    C --> D[Next Day: Start Fresh]
    D --> A
    
    style A fill:#e1bee7
    style B fill:#c5cae9
    style C fill:#b2dfdb
    style D fill:#fff9c4
```

**This works because:**
- Cognitive load stays manageable (one thing = one neural pathway)
- Hands-on practice cements learning same-day (not weeks later)
- Sharing creates social proof + community learning
- Fresh start each day prevents overwhelm

**Your curriculum isn't groundbreaking because of the content** (insulation physics is well-documented). **It's effective because of the delivery structure** - and that deserves highlighting in your report.

You asked for critique without flattery. Here it is: 

**Your reports aren't bad - they're bloated.** You've documented a genuinely well-designed training program, but the documentation itself gets in the way of appreciating the work. 

The merger strategy above will help you:
1. Cut the excess
2. Surface the real evidence
3. Make the pedagogy visible

Then the report will match the quality of the training itself.

{"language": "markdown", "code": "# Internship, Apprenticeship & Job Shadowing Framework

## BEIT Project Output 3 \- Implementation Guidelines

**Version**: 1.0 **Date**: October 2025 **Prepared by**: ITC Green Housing Technical Team **Implementing Partner**: Mosul Space Organization for Development

---

## Table of Contents

1. [Framework Purpose & Context](#1-purpose)  
2. [Career Pathway Design](#2-pathways)  
3. [Placement Process](#3-process)  
4. [Roles & Responsibilities](#4-roles)  
5. [Implementation Templates](#5-templates)  
6. [Quality Assurance](#6-quality)  
7. [Partner Directory](#7-partners)  
8. [Pilot Plan](#8-pilot)

---

## 1\. Framework Purpose & Context

### **Why This Framework Exists**

Mosul's green housing sector faces a **skills-to-employment gap**:

- **Trainers confirm**: *"CVs aren't trusted. We need to see people work with their hands."* (Zeina Tareq, Solar Expert)  
- **Fresh graduates struggle**: Limited professional networks, no portfolio of real projects, unclear entry points  
- **Employers hesitate**: Hiring is risky without evidence of competence; trial periods are standard

This framework provides **low-risk pathways** for trainees to gain practical experience, build portfolios, and transition into employment or entrepreneurship.

### **Three Different Career Outcomes**

The BEIT training modules prepare participants for **three distinct outcomes**, each requiring a different apprenticeship approach:

| Module | Career Goal | Apprenticeship Focus |
| :---- | :---- | :---- |
| **Insulation** | **Entrepreneurship** | Launch own energy consulting / retrofitting service |
| **Solar** | **Employment** | Join existing solar company as technician / installer |
| **Architecture** | **Awareness & Design** | Influence clients toward heritage-informed green design |

**Implication**: One-size-fits-all internship models don't work. We need **tailored pathways** for each track.

---

## 2\. Career Pathway Design

### **2.1 Pathway Levels (Least → Most Commitment)**

| Pathway | Duration | Structure | Stipend? | Best For |
| :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- |
| **Site Visit** | 1 day | Shadow ustādh on active project; observe, take notes, ask questions | No | Getting a feel for the work; breaking the ice |
| **Job Shadowing** | 1-2 weeks (2-3 days/week) | Follow mentor through full workflow: client meetings, site assessment, installation, follow-up | Small (5,000-10,000 IQD/day if possible) | Building confidence; understanding business flow |
| **Apprenticeship** | 1-3 months (3 days/week) | Supervised hands-on work: assist on installations, conduct measurements, draft proposals under guidance | Shared cost: IP/ITC covers part, company covers part (see 2.3) | Skill verification; portfolio building |
| **Internship** | 1 month full-time | Lead small project with mentor oversight; produce deliverable (ROI analysis, retrofit plan, design portfolio) | Small (100,000-150,000 IQD total) | Final step before employment or self-employment |

**Key Insight**: Start with **low-commitment** (site visit) to build trust, escalate to **high-commitment** (internship) as competence is proven.

---

### **2.2 Module-Specific Pathways**

#### **INSULATION TRACK (Entrepreneurship Path)**

**Goal**: Trainee launches own energy consulting / retrofitting service

**Pathway**:

1. **Shadow** an experienced energy auditor (Wifaq Ahmed, Omar Laith) on 2-3 home assessments  
2. **Apprentice** by conducting assessments under supervision; co-author ROI proposals  
3. **Solo pilot project**: Assess a real home (sourced by IP or trainer network), present findings to homeowner, implement one intervention (e.g., roof thermal paint)  
4. **Portfolio output**: Before/after photos, energy bill comparison, testimonial

**Key Relationships to Build**:

- **Suppliers**: SIKA, SMTC, Al-Ghanim (for material sourcing)  
- **Customers**: WhatsApp marketing, referrals from trainers  
- **Trainers**: Ongoing advice via WhatsApp community

**Success Metric**: Within 3 months post-training, trainee completes **1 paid retrofit project** and has **3 leads in pipeline**.

---

#### **SOLAR TRACK (Employment Path)**

**Goal**: Trainee joins existing solar company as technician / installer

**Pathway**:

1. **Site visit** to active solar installation (Voltage Co., Aqtab Al-Taqa, Chisage ESS)  
2. **Job shadow** lead installer for 1-2 weeks: system design, wiring, commissioning, troubleshooting  
3. **Apprenticeship** (1-2 months): Assist on 3-5 installations under supervision; learn quality standards  
4. **Trial hire**: Company offers 1-month paid trial (with IP/ITC subsidy—see 2.3); if successful, convert to full hire

**Portfolio output**: Photos of 3-5 completed systems, endorsement letter from mentor, hands-on test passed

**Key Partner Insight** (Hossam Al-Deen, Aqtab Al-Taqa):

*"I'd hire trainees if the institution pays their salary for the first 2 months while I assess their skills. After that, if they're good, I'll keep them on my payroll."*

**Implementation**: ITC/IP budget includes **salary subsidies** for 5-10 trainees (50,000 IQD/month × 2 months \= 100,000 IQD/trainee).

---

#### **ARCHITECTURE TRACK (Design & Awareness Path)**

**Goal**: Junior architects influence clients toward heritage-informed green design

**Pathway**:

1. **Shadow** senior architect (Yamama Salih, Anfal Yathrib) on client consultations; observe pitching process  
2. **Design apprenticeship**: Co-develop green retrofit plan for real client; learn to incorporate heritage principles (courtyards, thermal mass, natural ventilation)  
3. **Solo design project**: Each trainee works with 1 real client during training to produce heritage-informed design (presented on final day with homeowner present)  
4. **Design competition**: Post-training, all architects design the same model home (200m² retrofit); top 3 showcased at Green Home Festival

**Portfolio output**: 2-3 design presentations (with client testimonials), social media shares, competition entry

**Key Challenge**: *"Junior architects believe in green design, but think their bosses won't approve."*

**Strategy**: Invite bosses to **final presentation day** where clients react positively to designs — market demand shifts mindset.

---

### **2.3 De-Risking Hiring: The Salary Subsidy Model**

**Problem**: Employers hesitate to hire because fresh graduates are unproven.

**Solution** (inspired by Hossam Al-Deen's suggestion):

| Cost Component | Who Pays | Amount (IQD) | Rationale |
| :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- |
| **Month 1-2 Salary** | IP / ITC | 50,000/month | De-risk hiring; employer assesses skills without financial commitment |
| **Supervision time** | Employer (in-kind) | — | Mentor invests time to train; reciprocated by cheap labor |
| **Month 3+ Salary** | Employer | 150,000-300,000/month | If trainee proves competent, employer hires them fully |

**Budget Estimate**: 10 trainees × 100,000 IQD (2 months) \= **1,000,000 IQD total** (\~$700 USD).

**ROI**: If even 50% convert to full hires, IP has created **5 new jobs** in green sector at $140/job — highly cost-effective.

---

## 3\. Placement Process

### **Step-by-Step Workflow**

```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ PHASE 1: MATCHMAKING (Week 1 post-training)                │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ 1. Trainers post available slots in WhatsApp group          │
│    Example: "Voltage Co. needs 2 apprentices for Nov"      │
│ 2. Trainees submit 1-page portfolio (see Template A)        │
│ 3. Mentor reviews portfolios, shortlists 2-3 candidates     │
│ 4. 10-min hands-on test (e.g., "Calculate U-value for this  │
│    wall assembly" or "Wire this inverter connection")       │
│ 5. Mentor selects 1 candidate; IP facilitates agreement     │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ PHASE 2: ONBOARDING (Day 1)                                │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ 1. Sign Trilateral Placement Agreement (see Template B)     │
│ 2. Mentor briefs trainee: safety rules, task list, goals    │
│ 3. IP provides safety checklist (see Template E)            │
│ 4. Trainee receives Learning Plan (see Template C)          │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ PHASE 3: SUPERVISED WORK (Weeks 1-8)                       │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ 1. Trainee assists on real projects under supervision       │
│ 2. Weekly 15-min check-in (mentor + trainee + IP)          │
│ 3. Trainee documents work: photos, notes, measurements      │
│ 4. Mentor provides feedback, adjusts task complexity        │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ PHASE 4: EVALUATION & NEXT STEPS (Final week)              │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ 1. Mentor completes Evaluation Rubric (see Template D)      │
│ 2. Trainee presents portfolio piece (photos + numbers)      │
│ 3. Decision: Hire full-time? Extend apprenticeship? End?    │
│ 4. IP collects documentation for M&E (photos, testimonial)  │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

---

## 4\. Roles & Responsibilities

### **Trilateral Partnership**

| Role | Responsibilities | Commitments |
| :---- | :---- | :---- |
| **Implementing Partner (IP)** | \- Match trainees with mentors \- Provide salary subsidies (Months 1-2) \- Monitor placements (weekly check-ins) \- Facilitate agreements, insurance, safety \- Collect M\&E data | \- Budget: 100,000 IQD/trainee for subsidies \- Staff time: 2 hrs/week per placement for coordination |
| **Mentor / Host Employer** | \- Supervise trainee on real projects \- Provide feedback (weekly 15-min check-ins) \- Assess competence (final evaluation) \- Decide: hire, extend, or end? | \- In-kind: Supervision time (5-10 hrs/week) \- Commitment: Hire trainee if competent (Month 3+) |
| **Trainee** | \- Show up on time, follow safety rules \- Document work (photos, measurements) \- Ask questions, seek feedback \- Build portfolio piece for final presentation | \- Time: 3 days/week (or as agreed) \- Output: Portfolio piece (photos \+ numbers page) |

This mirrors what we emphasized in the ToT.
   751	
   752	---
   753	
   754	## 2\) What participants actually do
   755	
   756	### A) Hands-on “stations” (small groups)
   757	
   758	We split the room (\~20 people) into small groups that **rotate across 3 stations** to touch materials, run quick trials, and take photos, then regroup for reflection.
   759	
   760	**Examples to pick from (use 3 at a time):**
   761	
   762	5. **Insulation:** roof board demo (EPS/mineral wool/plaster), gap-sealing test, window/curtain heat feel test, simple infiltration demo.  
   763	6. **Solar:** dusty vs. clean panel output check (demo), component ID & compatibility, torque/earthing basics (classroom model).  
   764	7. **Architecture:** 150 m² façade/shading tweak on a base plan, thermal mass vs. reflectivity sketch drill, code checklist spot-check.
   765	
   766	Stations reduce overload and keep it real. Groups photograph their steps/results.
   767	
   768	### B) Safety & setup (always first)
   769	
   770	Clear the area; control dust; gloves/eye protection; tools checked. Prep pre-cut pieces and labeled thicknesses so trials are quick and safe.
   771	
   772	### C) Tiny take-home practice
   773	
   774	Break a **tile (kāshi)** or prep a small roof/wall **sample**; each participant takes one **home to observe** (e.g., feel, condensation, heat under sun).
   775	
   776	### D) Show your work (photos/short clips)
   777	
   778	Participants capture **short portrait clips** and **3–5 clear photos** (good composition) as learning evidence and to raise awareness.
   779	
   780	### E) Reason with **kWh/U-value**, not “amps × IQD”
   781	
   782	Use U-value references and kWh-based savings to explain benefit and **simple ROI**. **Verify any numbers locally** before claiming ranges.
   783	
   784	### F) Reflect & present
   785	
   786	Timed break → **group share-back** of best learnings (1–2 minutes per group). This closes the loop and keeps attention on what matters.
   787	
   788	---

   793	
   794	| Step | What happens |
   795	| :---- | :---- |
   796	| 0 — Setup | Safety check, clear area, pieces/tools ready. |
   797	| 1 — Grouping | Split into small groups (works well for \~20 ppl). |
   798	| 2 — Stations | Rotate across 3 stations; run short trials; take photos. |
   799	| 3 — Take-home | Each person takes a tile/sample for home observation. |
   800	| 4 — Numbers | Use **U-value → kWh → ROI**; avoid “amps × IQD.” |
   801	| 5 — Media | Capture **≤30s** clip \+ photo set with basic quality. |
   802	| 6 — Share-back | Quick group presentations after a timed break. |
   803	
   804	### 3.2 Documentation to collect (per group)
   805	
   806	8. **Photo set:** 3–5 images (stations \+ take-home piece).  
   807	9. **Short video:** ≤30s (portrait is fine) showing the activity or idea.  
   808	10. **Numbers page:** U-value used, kWh logic for savings, quick ROI (local prices).
